description: Kartlis Deda (meaning 'Mother of Kartvel' or 'Mother of Georgians') is a monumental 20-meter aluminum statue crowning Sololaki Hill overlooking Tbilisi, erected in 1958 to commemorate the capital's 1,500th anniversary. Designed by prominent Georgian sculptor Elguja Amashukeli (who received the prestigious Shota Rustaveli State Prize for this work in 1966), the towering figure depicts a woman in traditional Georgian national dress embodying the national character through powerful symbolism: her left hand holds a bowl of wine representing Georgian hospitality and welcoming spirit toward friends, while her right hand raises a sword symbolizing fierce determination to defend independence and sovereignty against enemies. The statue's creation history reveals fascinating complexity—Amashukeli originally sculpted a temporary wooden version in 1958 which proved so popular that authorities decided to make it permanent, covering it in aluminum in 1963 to protect against weather damage. The sculptor initially titled his work simply 'Capital,' but the public embraced the more evocative 'Mother of Kartvel' name that stuck. Interestingly, Amashukeli later modified the statue's features to make the figure more feminine in appearance, transforming what was originally a more masculine image. The original 1958-1963 statue served until 1997 when it was replaced with an identical new version to preserve this iconic landmark for future generations. The nomination process for Amashukeli's Rustaveli Prize reflected unusual Soviet-era collaboration, coming from the staff of the Kirov Machine-Tool Plant together with the Union of Artists and Union of Architects—industrial workers and arts organizations jointly recognizing cultural achievement. The statue stands atop Sololaki Hill in Tbilisi's oldest residential neighborhood, an area where 19th-century Georgia's wealthiest merchants built European-styled mansions that have transformed into today's trendiest restaurants, coffee shops, and bars. Visitors reach Kartlis Deda via the cable car from Rike Park to Narikala Fortress followed by a 5-minute walk, by hiking the steep but paved stairway on Betlemi Street, or via buses #37 or #74 to Sololaki with a 15-minute uphill walk. The hilltop location provides breathtaking 360-degree panoramic views encompassing Narikala Fortress, Old Town's traditional architecture, the Mtkvari River, modern Tbilisi developments, and on clear days, snow-capped Caucasus Mountains framing the horizon, making the viewpoint arguably more significant than the statue itself for many visitors.
highlights: The 20-meter aluminum statue depicts a woman in Georgian national dress holding dual symbols of national character: a bowl of wine in her left hand welcoming friends with legendary Georgian hospitality, and a sword in her right hand ready to defend against enemies with fierce determination.

Sculptor Elguja Amashukeli received the prestigious Shota Rustaveli State Prize in 1966 for this iconic work, with the unusual distinction of being nominated jointly by the Kirov Machine-Tool Plant workers alongside the Union of Artists and Union of Architects.

The statue evolved through three versions: the original 1958 temporary wooden sculpture, the 1963 permanent aluminum-covered version, and the 1997 replacement with an identical new statue, each preserving Amashukeli's vision while adapting to preservation needs.

Sololaki Hill's elevated position provides breathtaking 360-degree panoramic views of Tbilisi including Narikala Fortress, Old Town's traditional architecture, the Mtkvari River, modern districts, and on clear days, snow-capped Caucasus Mountains on the horizon.

The statue was originally titled simply 'Capital' by Amashukeli, but the public renamed it 'Mother of Kartvel' (Mother of Georgians), with the more evocative name becoming permanent despite the sculptor's preference for his simpler original.
Amashukeli later modified the statue to make the figure more feminine in appearance, transforming what was originally a more masculine image into the distinctly womanly form visitors see today.
An interactive QR code at the site connects visitors to a voice recording allowing 'Mother Georgia' to speak, adding contemporary digital engagement to the Soviet-era monument.

The hilltop location adjacent to Narikala Fortress creates natural integration with Tbilisi's most ancient landmark, accessible via the modern cable car system connecting Rike Park, the fortress, and the statue area.

The surrounding Sololaki neighborhood represents Tbilisi's oldest residential area where 19th-century wealthy merchants' European mansions now house trendy restaurants, specialty coffee shops, and craft bars creating vibrant cultural atmosphere.

The statue faces outward toward the city rather than toward approaching visitors, meaning the monument can only be viewed from the side when standing beside it, with better full-figure views available from distances below on the hillside or cable car.
tips: Visit during spring (April-June) or autumn (September-October) for mild weather and clear skies providing optimal viewing conditions and comfortable hiking temperatures if ascending on foot.

Arrive before noon or in late afternoon to avoid peak crowds and capture the best light for panoramic photography, with sunset offering particularly magical golden-hour illumination as city lights begin twinkling.
Avoid weekend afternoons when tourist groups peak, opting instead for weekday mornings or evenings for quieter, more contemplative experiences with the monument and views.
Take the cable car from Rike Park to Narikala Fortress (easiest route) followed by a short 5-minute walk to the statue, offering dramatic aerial views during the ascent as an experience in itself.
Alternatively, hike the steep but paved Betlemi Street stairway for active journeys rewarded with accomplishment and changing perspectives as you ascend through residential neighborhoods.
Wear comfortable, sturdy shoes whether taking the cable car (for uneven hilltop terrain) or hiking (for steep stairs and paths), as the area involves significant walking on varied surfaces.
Bring water bottles especially in summer when the exposed hilltop becomes hot and dehydrating, with minimal shade available around the statue viewing area.
Avoid midday summer heat and rainy winter conditions when climbs become exhausting or slippery, instead timing visits for cooler morning/evening hours or clear weather days.

Photograph the statue from distances below rather than up close, as the monument's positioning at the hill's edge and outward-facing orientation prevents classic frontal views when standing beside it.
Scan the QR code at the site to access the interactive voice recording allowing 'Mother Georgia' to speak, an engaging digital feature that many visitors miss entirely.

Explore the charming Sololaki neighborhood after visiting the statue, discovering trendy cafes, specialty coffee shops, local crafts, and 19th-century European mansion architecture transformed into contemporary establishments.
Expect vendor stalls selling overpriced souvenirs in the immediate statue area, especially during peak tourist season—purchase mementos elsewhere in Tbilisi for better value if interested.
vibe: Kartlis Deda emanates powerful symbolic presence representing Georgian national identity, though the experience divides between the statue itself (often underwhelming up close) and the spectacular hilltop panoramas (consistently breathtaking). The approach via cable car builds anticipation as glass cabins glide above terracotta rooftops and green hillsides, depositing visitors near Narikala Fortress for the short walk to the monument area. The exposed hilltop location feels windswept and open, lacking the sheltered intimacy of enclosed attractions, with the 20-meter aluminum figure looming overhead in traditional dress, bowl and sword raised against the sky. Up close, the statue reveals its age and weathering—aluminum surfaces showing wear, details less refined than expected, proportions appearing awkward from certain angles, and the outward-facing orientation meaning you view her profile rather than her face, creating initial disappointment for visitors expecting grandeur. However, turning away from the statue toward Tbilisi spread below instantly transforms the experience as 360-degree panoramas unfold: ancient Narikala Fortress walls nearby, Old Town's maze of buildings cascading toward the Mtkvari River, the Bridge of Peace's illuminated arc, Sameba Cathedral's golden dome gleaming, modern districts stretching to foothills, and on clear days, Caucasus peaks forming the distant horizon. The viewing area attracts mixed crowds—Georgian families on weekend outings treating it as a normal recreational spot, international tourists with cameras and selfie sticks, young couples seeking romantic sunset moments, and locals who barely glance at the statue while enjoying city views and fresh hilltop breezes. Vendor stalls create slightly commercial atmosphere with persistent (but not aggressive) souvenir hawkers, trinkets displayed on folding tables, and the occasional tour group bottleneck during peak afternoon hours. The symbolic duality of wine and sword resonates differently for visitors—some find it profoundly moving encapsulation of Georgian character (generous hospitality balanced with fierce independence), while others see it as dated Soviet-era nationalist iconography lacking contemporary relevance. The overall emotional register tends toward mild anticlimax regarding the statue itself followed by growing appreciation for the location's panoramic magnificence, with most visitors concluding the views justify the visit even if the monument disappoints.
expectations: Visitors expect an impressive, detailed, beautiful statue rivaling famous monuments worldwide, anticipating intricate craftsmanship and overwhelming artistic grandeur when standing before the 20-meter figure.

Many assume they'll achieve classic frontal photographs capturing the full statue with dramatic Tbilisi backdrop, not realizing the monument's positioning and outward orientation prevents these idealized shots from the viewing platform.

Tourists often expect the statue itself to be the main attraction and highlight of the visit, not understanding that the panoramic city views typically prove more memorable and photographically rewarding.

First-time visitors frequently anticipate a quiet, contemplative monument experience without realizing the area includes vendor stalls, souvenir hawkers, and peak-season crowds creating commercial atmosphere.

Many travelers expect straightforward access and easy viewing without understanding the steep climbs, exposed hilltop conditions, and the fact that best views of the statue itself come from distances below rather than beside it.
reality: Up close the statue appears less beautiful than promotional images suggest, with aluminum weathering, proportional awkwardness from certain angles, limited visible details, and the side-view positioning preventing the dramatic frontal perspectives visitors imagine, creating initial disappointment.

The statue's outward-facing orientation toward the city means visitors standing beside it can only view her profile, never her face directly, with better full-figure photographs actually achievable from distances below on the hillside or from the cable car rather than the viewing platform.

The breathtaking 360-degree panoramic views of Tbilisi, Narikala Fortress, Old Town, the Mtkvari River, modern districts, and distant Caucasus Mountains represent the visit's true highlight, with location trumping sculpture in visitor memories and photo collections.

The immediate area features numerous vendor stalls selling overpriced souvenirs with persistent (though not aggressive) hawking, especially during peak tourist season, creating commercial atmosphere that contrasts with expectations of serene monument contemplation.

Reaching the statue requires either steep uphill hiking on Betlemi Street stairs (exhausting in summer heat), a 5-minute walk from the cable car station over uneven terrain, or bus routes with 15-minute uphill walks, plus the exposed hilltop offers minimal shade making midday summer visits particularly challenging without adequate water and sun protection.
unique_facts: The original 1958 statue was constructed from wood as a temporary installation for Tbilisi's 1,500th anniversary celebration, only becoming permanent in 1963 when public enthusiasm prompted authorities to preserve it with aluminum covering.

Sculptor Elguja Amashukeli originally titled his work simply 'Capital,' but the public renamed it 'Mother of Kartvel' (Mother of Georgians), with the popular name overriding the artist's preference and becoming permanent.

Amashukeli later modified the statue to make the figure more feminine in appearance, transforming what was originally a more masculine image into the distinctly womanly form that stands today, showing artistic evolution even after installation.

The statue received an unusual Rustaveli Prize nomination in 1966 from the Kirov Machine-Tool Plant workers jointly with the Union of Artists and Union of Architects, reflecting Soviet-era collaboration between industrial laborers and arts organizations recognizing cultural achievement.

The 1958-1963 original statue served for 34 years until replaced with an identical new version in 1997, meaning today's monument is technically the third iteration (wooden original, aluminum-covered version, 1997 replacement) of Amashukeli's design.

An interactive QR code at the site connects visitors to a voice recording allowing 'Mother Georgia' to speak, adding 21st-century digital engagement to the Soviet-era monument in an unusual blend of historical and contemporary technology.

The statue's dual symbolism—wine bowl for friends, sword for enemies—has been interpreted as encapsulating not just Georgian character but specifically Soviet-era defensive nationalism mixed with hospitality, making it both timeless and time-bound.

The surrounding Sololaki neighborhood represents Tbilisi's oldest residential area where 19th-century Georgia's wealthiest merchants built European-styled mansions that have gentrified into today's trendiest restaurants, coffee shops, and bars.

The monument stands at Tbilisi's highest easily accessible point, providing views that on exceptionally clear days extend to snow-capped Caucasus Mountains forming the horizon approximately 50-60 kilometers away.

The best photographic views of the statue itself are paradoxically not from the viewing platform beside it but from distances below on the hillside or from the cable car, where the full figure and its relationship to the cityscape become visible.

The statue's placement atop Sololaki Hill adjacent to ancient Narikala Fortress creates symbolic continuity between Georgia's defensive heritage (the fortress) and modern national identity (Mother Georgia), though separated by centuries.

During peak summer season and weekends, cable car queues to reach the statue area can extend to 30+ minutes in heat, with the exposed hilltop offering minimal shade, making timing and preparation crucial for comfortable visits.
surprises: The statue proves less impressive up close than in photographs, with aluminum weathering, awkward proportions from certain angles, and limited visible details creating disappointment for visitors expecting artistic grandeur comparable to world-famous monuments.

You cannot photograph the statue frontally from the viewing platform beside it—she faces outward toward the city, meaning visitors only see her profile, with better full-figure shots ironically requiring distance below on the hillside or from the cable car.

The panoramic city views completely overshadow the statue itself in visitor memories and photo collections, with most people concluding the location's 360-degree vistas justify the visit regardless of monument quality.

Vendor stalls and souvenir hawkers create unexpected commercial atmosphere in the immediate statue area, especially during peak season, contrasting with expectations of contemplative national monument serenity.

The QR code voice recording allowing 'Mother Georgia' to speak surprises tech-savvy visitors who discover this interactive digital feature, though many miss it entirely without advance knowledge or visible signage.

The steep, exhausting climb via Betlemi Street stairs catches unprepared visitors off-guard, particularly in summer heat, with the 'short walk' from cable car station also involving more uphill effort over uneven terrain than expected.

The exposed hilltop offers virtually no shade, making midday summer visits brutally hot and dehydrating, surprising tourists who didn't anticipate Mediterranean-level sun exposure requiring water, hats, and sunscreen.

The statue's original wooden 1958 version was only meant to be temporary for the anniversary celebration, with permanent status only granted after unexpected public enthusiasm—the monument's existence resulted from popular demand rather than initial planning.

Sculptor Amashukeli modified the statue after installation to make it more feminine, transforming a more masculine original figure, meaning today's monument represents artistic evolution rather than the sculptor's initial vision.

The best views of Kartlis Deda come from below rather than beside her, creating the counterintuitive situation where approaching the monument gradually reduces its visual impact until you're beside it seeing only her profile.

The charming Sololaki neighborhood with its gentrified 19th-century mansions housing trendy cafes and craft bars lies just down the hillside, offering excellent post-monument exploration that guidebooks rarely emphasize.

On clear days, the Caucasus Mountains appear on the horizon approximately 50-60 kilometers away, a spectacular sight that requires specific weather conditions and surprises visitors who weren't aware this geographic feature was visible from Tbilisi.
